# free-for-dev

Developers and Open Source authors now have a massive amount of services offering free tiers, but it can be hard to find them all in order to make informed decisions.

This is a list of software (SaaS, PaaS, IaaS, etc.) and other offerings that have free tiers for developers.

The scope of this particular list is limited to things infrastructure developers (System Administrator, DevOps Practitioners, etc.) are likely to find useful. We love all the free services out there, but it would be good to keep it on topic. It's a bit of a grey line at times so this is a bit opinionated; do not be offended if I do not accept your contribution.

You can help by sending Pull Requests to add more services. Once I have a good set of links in this README file, I'll look into a better layout for the information and links (help with that is appreciated too).

NOTE: This list is only for as-a-Service offerings, not for self-hosted software. For a service to be eligible it has to offer a Free Tier and not just a free trial. If the Free Tier is time bucketed it has to be at least a year.

# Source Code Repos

  • bitbucket.org â€” Unlimited public and private repos (Git and Mercurial) for up to 5 users with Pipelines for CI/CD
  • chiselapp.com â€” Unlimited public and private Fossil repositories
  • github.com â€” Unlimited number of public repositories
  • about.gitlab.com â€” Unlimited public and private Git repos with unlimited collaborators
  • visualstudio.com â€” Unlimited private repos (Git and TFS) for up to 5 users/team
  • plasticscm.com â€” Free for individuals, OSS and nonprofit organizations
  • cloud.google.com â€” Free private Git repositories hosted on Google Cloud Platform. Supports syncing with existing GitHub and Bitbucket repos. Free Beta for up to 500 MB of storage
  • codebasehq.com â€” One free project with 100 MB space and 2 users
  • NotABug â€” NotABug.org is a free-software code collaboration platform for freely licensed projects, Git-based
  • perforce.com â€” Free 1GB Cloud and Git, Mercurial, or SVN repositories.
  • projectlocker.com â€” One free private project (Git and Subversion) with 50 MB space

# Artifact Repos

  • bintray.com â€” JFrog Bintray hosts Open Source projects for free, and supports Docker, Maven, NuGet, npm, Debian, RPM, Conan, Vagrant, Opkg, yum, and also home to JCenter the most comprehensive collection of Maven artifacts.
  • central.sonatype.org â€” The default artifact repository for Apache Maven, SBT and other build systems.
  • packagecloud.io â€” Easy to use repository hosting for: Maven, RPM, DEB, PyPi and RubyGem packages (has free tier).
  • cloudsmith.io â€” Simple, secure and centralised repository service for Java/Maven, RedHat, Debian, Python, Ruby, Vagrant +more. Free tier + free for open source.
  • jitpack.io â€” Maven repository for JVM and Android projects on GitHub, free for public projects.

# Tools for Teams and Collaboration

  • scinote.net â€” Scientific data management and team collaboration. One Team with unlimited number of users, backup and 1 GB storage space
  • appear.in â€” One click video conversations, for free
  • meet.jit.si â€” One click video conversations, screen sharing, for free
  • flowdock.com â€” Chat and inbox, free for teams up to 5
  • slack.com â€” Free for unlimited users with some feature limitations
  • gitter.im â€” Chat, for GitHub. Unlimited public and private rooms, free for teams up to 25
  • hangouts.google.com â€” One place for all your conversations, for free, need a Google account
  • seafile.com â€” Private or cloud storage, file sharing, sync, discussions. Private version is full. Cloud version has just 1 GB
  • yammer.com â€” Private social network standalone or for MS Office 365. Free with a bit less admin tools and users management features
  • helpmonks.com â€” Shared inbox for teams, free for Open Source and nonprofit organizations
  • typetalk.in â€” Share and discuss ideas with your team through instant messaging on the web or on your mobile
  • talky.io â€” Free group video chat. Anonymous. Peerâ€‘toâ€‘peer. No plugins, signup, or payment required
  • sourcetalk.net â€” Code discussion tool, free for open code talks
  • helplightning.com â€” Help over video with augmented reality. Free without analytics, encryption, support
  • evernote.com â€” Tool for organizing information. Share your notes and work together with others
  • doodle.com â€” The scheduling tool you'll actually use. Find a date for a meeting two times faster
  • sendtoinc.com â€” Share links, notes, files and have discussions. Free for 3 and 100 MB
  • zoom.us â€” Secure Video and Web conferencing, add-ons available. Free limited to 40 minutes
  • ideascale.com â€” Allow clients to submit ideas and vote, free for 25 members in 1 community
  • wistia.com â€” Video hosting with viewer analytics, HD video delivery and marketing tools to help understand your visitors, 25 videos and Wistia branded player
  • cnverg.com â€” Real-time shared visual workspace, whiteboard, GitHub integration. Free 5 GB, 5 spaces and 5 collaborators, no GitHub repos
  • flock.com â€” A faster way for your team to communicate. Free Unlimited Messages, Channels, Users, Apps & Integrations
  • Igloo â€” Internal portal for sharing documents, blogs and calendars etc. Free for up to 10 users.
  • riot.im â€” A decentralized communication tool built on Matrix. Group chats, direct messaging, encrypted file transfers, voice and video chats, and easy integration with other services.
  • Microsoft Teams â€” Microsoft Teams is a chat-based digital hub that brings conversations, content, and apps together in one place all from a single experience. Free for up to 300 users.

  • blamewarrior.com â€” Tool to automatically assign reviewers for new pullÂ requests and track statistics of review process, free for Open Source
  • gerrithub.io â€” Gerrit code review for GitHub repositories for free
  • reviewable.io â€” Code review for GitHub repositories, free for public or personal repos

  • golangci.com â€” Automated Go (golang) code review service for GitHub pull requests.

# Automated Browser Testing

  • gridlastic.com â€” Selenium Grid testing with free plan up to 4 simultaneous selenium nodes/10 grid starts/4,000 test minutes/month
  • saucelabs.com â€” Cross browser testing, Selenium testing and mobile testing, free for Open Source
  • browserstack.com â€” Manual and automated browser testing, free for Open Source
  • everystep-automation.com â€” Records and replays all steps made in a web browser and creates scripts,... free with fewer options
  • Applitools.com â€” smart visual validation for web, native mobile and desktop apps. Integrates with almost all automation solutions (like Selenium and Karma) and remote runners (Sauce Labs, Browser Stack). free for open source. A free tier for a single user with limited checkpoints per week.
  • checkbot.io â€” Browser extension that tests if your website follows 50+ SEO, speed and security best practices. Free tier for smaller websites.

# Security and PKI

  • pyup.io â€” Monitory Python dependencies for security vulnerabilities and update them automatically. Free for one private project, unlimited projects for open source.
  • threatconnect.com â€” Threat intelligence: It is designed for individual researchers, analysts and organizations who are starting to learn about cyber threat intelligence. Free up to 3 Users
  • crypteron.com â€” Cloud-first, developer-friendly security platform prevents data breaches in .NET and Java applications
  • snyk.io â€” Snyk found and reported several vulnerabilities in the package.Limited to 1 private project (unlimited for open source projects)
  • letsencrypt.org â€” Free SSL Certificate Authority with certs trusted by all major browsers
  • globalsign.com â€” Free SSL certificates for Open Source
  • Okta â€” User management, authentication and authorization. Free for up to 1000 monthly active users.
  • auth0.com â€” Hosted free for development SSO
  • ringcaptcha.com â€” Tools to use phone number as id, available for free
  • ssllabs.com â€” Very deep analysis of the configuration of any SSL web server
  • qualys.com â€” Find web app vulnerabilities, audit for OWASP Risks
  • alienvault.com â€” Uncovers compromised systems in your network
  • duo.com â€” Two-factor authentication (2FA) for website or app. Free 10 users, all authentication methods, unlimited, integrations, hardware tokens
  • tinfoilsecurity.com â€” Automated vulnerability scanning. Free plan allows weekly XSS scans
  • acunetix.com â€” Free vulnerability and network scanning for 3 targets
  • ponycheckup.com â€” An automated security checkup tool for Django websites
  • foxpass.com â€” Hosted LDAP and RADIUS. Easy per-user logins to servers, VPNs and wireless networks. Free for 10 users
  • opswat.com â€” Security Monitoring of computers, devices, applications, configurations,... Free 25 users and 30 days history
  • bitninja.io â€” Botnet protection through a blacklist, free plan only reports limited information on each attack
  • onelogin.com â€” Identity as a Service (IDaaS), Single Sign-On Identity Provider, Cloud SSO IdP, 3 company apps and 5 personal apps, unlimited users
  • logintc.com â€” Two-factor authentication (2FA) by push notifications, free for 10 users, VPN, Websites and SSH
  • report-uri.io â€” CSP and HPKP violation reporting
  • cloudsploit.com â€” Amazon Web Services (AWS) security and compliance auditing and monitoring
  • Have I been pwned? â€” REST API for fetching the information on the breaches.
  • Internet.nl â€” Test for modern Internet Standards like IPv6, DNSSEC, HTTPS, DMARC, STARTTLS and DANE
  • Mozilla Observatory â€” Find and fix security vulnerabilities in your site.

  • appbeat.io â€” Website monitoring, 3 monitors free. They offer very reliable and affordable monitor service.

  • assertible.com â€” Automated API testing and monitoring. Free plans for teams and individuals.

  • letsmonitor.org â€” TLS certificate expiration and connectivity monitoring with email and SMS alerts.

  • opsgenie.com â€” Powerful alerting and on-call management for operating always-on services. Free up to 5 users.

  • rollbar.com â€” Exception and error monitoring, free plan with 5,000 errors/month, unlimited users, 30 days retention

  • sentry.io â€” Sentry tracks app exceptions in real-time, has a small free plan. Free, unrestricted use if self-hosted

  • algolia.com â€” Hosted search-as-you-type (instant). Free hacker plan up to 10,000 documents and 100,000 operations. Bigger free plans available for community/Open Source projects

  • searchly.com â€” Free 2 indices and 5 MB storage
  • indexisto.com â€” Site search, free 10 million documents index limit with advertisement block

# CDN and Protection

  • cloudflare.com â€” Basic service is free, good for a blog, it also offers a free SSL certificate service
  • bootstrapcdn.com â€” CDN for bootstrap, bootswatch and fontawesome.io
  • cdnjs.com â€” CDN for JavaScript libraries, CSS libraries, SWF, images, etc
  • jsdelivr.com â€” CDN of OSS (JS, CSS, fonts) for developers and webmasters, accepts PRs to add more
  • developers.google.com â€” The Google Hosted Libraries is a content distribution network for the most popular, Open Source JavaScript libraries
  • asp.net â€” The Microsoft Ajax CDN hosts popular third party JavaScript libraries such as jQuery and enables you to easily add them to your Web application
  • toranproxy.com â€” Proxy for Packagist and GitHub. Never fail CD. Free for personal use, 1 developer, no support
  • rawgit.com â€” Free limited traffic, serves raw files directly from GitHub with proper Content-Type headers
  • incapsula.com â€” Free CDN and DDoS protection
  • Web Support Revolution â€” Free CDN, backup, firewall, antivirus and monitoring.
  • section.io â€” A simple way to spin up and manage a complete Varnish Cache solution. Supposedly free forever for one site
  • netdepot.com â€” First 100 GB free/month
  • speeder.io â€” Uses KeyCDN. Automatic image optimization and free CDN boost. Free and does not require any server changes
  • jare.io â€” You should log in using your GitHub account and register your domain. Uses AWS CloudFront

# PaaS

  • wedeploy.com â€” WeDeploy gives you predefined services that can speed up your development process. Free plan: 1 GB Transfer, 1 GB Memory, 1 CPU, 512 MB Storage, 2 Service Instances, 2 Projects
  • cloud.google.com â€” Google App Engine gives 28 instance hours/day free, 1 GB NoSQL database and more
  • engineyard.com â€” Engine Yard provides 500 free hours
  • azure.microsoft.com â€” MS Azure gives USD 200 worth of free usage for a trial
  • appharbor.com â€” A .Net PaaS that provides 1 free worker
  • heroku.com â€” Host your apps in the cloud, free for single process apps
  • firebase.google.com â€” Build real-time apps, the free plan has 100 max connections, 10 GB data transfer, 1 GB data storage, 1 GB hosting storage and 10 GB hosting transfer
  • bluemix.net â€” IBM PaaS with a monthly free allowance
  • outsystems.com â€” Enterprise web development PaaS for on-premise or cloud, free "personal environment" offering allows for unlimited code and up to 1 GB database
  • scn.sap.com â€” The in-memory Platform-as-a-Service offering from SAP. Free developer accounts come with 1 GB structured, 1 GB unstructured, 1 GB of Git data and allow you to run HTML5, Java and HANA XS apps
  • mendix.com â€” Rapid Application Development for Enterprises, unlimited number of free sandbox environments supporting 10 users, 100 MB of files and 100 MB database storage each
  • pythonanywhere.com â€” Cloud Python app hosting. Beginner account is free, 1 Python web application at your-username.pythonanywhere.com domain, 512 MB private file storage, one MySQL database
  • configure.it â€” Mobile app development platform, free for 2 projects, limited features but no resource limits
  • zeit.co/now â€” Managed platform for Node.js, static sites and Docker deployments. Limited to 3 concurrent instances, 1 GB storage and 1 GB bandwidth for OSS projects (source files are exposed on a public URL)
  • sandstorm.io â€” Sandstorm is an open source operating system for personal and private clouds. Free plan offers 200 MB storage and 5 grains free
  • gearhost.com â€” Platform for .NET and PHP apps. 256 MB of RAM for free on a shared server with limited resources
  • glitch.com â€” Free unlimited public/private hosting with features such as code sharing and real-time collaboration

# BaaS

  • blockspring.com â€” Cloud functions. Free for 5 million runs/month
  • postgress.com â€” Mobile backend, starter plan has unlimited requests/second, with 1 GB of data storage. Enterprise application support
  • backendless.com â€” Mobile and Web Baas, with 1 GB file storage free, push notifications 50000/month, and 1000 data objects in table.
  • hasura.io â€” Platform to build and deploy app backends fast, free for single node cluster.
  • pusher.com â€” Free, unlimited push notifications for 2000 monthly active users. A single API for iOS and Android devices.
  • layer.com â€” The full-stack building block for communications
  • quickblox.com â€” A communication backend for instant messaging, video and voice calling and push notifications
  • pushbots.com â€” Push notification service. Free for up to 1.5 million pushes/month
  • onesignal.com â€” Unlimited free push notifications
  • getstream.io â€” Build scalable news feeds and activity streams in a few hours instead of weeks, free for 3 million feed updates/month
  • tyk.io â€” API management with authentication, quotas, monitoring and analytics. Free cloud offering
  • iron.io â€” Async task processing (like AWS Lambda) with free tier and 1 month free trial
  • nstack.com â€” Async task processing (like AWS Lambda). 10 free private services and unlimited free public services
  • pubnub.com â€” Free push notifications for up to 1 million messages/month and 100 active daily devices
  • pushtechnology.com â€” Real-time Messaging for browsers, smartphones and everyone. 100 concurrent connections. Free 10 GB data/month
  • webtask.io â€” Run code with an HTTP call. No provisioning. No deployment
  • zapier.com â€” Connect the apps you use, to automate tasks. 5 zaps, every 15 minutes and 100 tasks/month
  • stackstorm.com â€” Event-driven automation for apps, services and workflows, free without flow, access control, LDAP,...
  • simperium.com â€” Move data everywhere instantly and automatically, multi-platform, unlimited sending and storage of structured data, max. 2,500 users/month
  • pushcrew.com â€” Push notification service. Unlimited notifications up to 2000 Subscribers
  • streamdata.io â€” Turns any REST API into an event-driven streaming API. Free plan up to 1 million messages and 10 concurrent connections
  • posthook.io â€” Job Scheduling Service. Allows you to schedule requests for specific times. 500 scheduled requests/month free.
  • paraio.com â€” Backend service API with flexible authentication, full-text search and caching. Free for 1 app, 1GB app data.

  • pages.github.com â€” Hosting static site directly from GitHub repository

  • netlify.com â€” Builds, deploy and hosts static site or app, free for 100 GB data and 100 GB/month bandwidth
  • sanity.io â€“Â Hosted backend for structured content with customizeable MIT licensed editor built with React. Unlimited projects. 3 users, 2 datasets, 500k API CDN requests, 5GB assets for free per project
  • pantheon.io â€” Drupal and WordPress hosting, automated DevOps and scalable infrastructure. Free for developers and agencies
  • acquia.com â€” Hosting for Drupal sites. Free tier for developers. Free development tools (such as Acquia Dev Desktop) also available

# STUN, WebRTC, Web Socket Servers and Other Routers

  • scaledrone.com â€” Push messaging service. Free for up to 20 simultaneous connections and 100,000 messages/day
  • pusher.com â€” Realtime messaging service. Free for up to 100 simultaneous connections and 200,000 messages/day
  • stun:stun.l.google.com:19302 â€” Google STUN
  • stun:global.stun.twilio.com:3478?transport=udp â€” Twilio STUN
  • segment.com â€” Hub to translate and route events to other third party services. 100,000 events/month free
  • ngrok.com â€” Expose locally running servers over a tunnel to a public URL.
  • cloudamqp.com â€” RabbitMQ as a Service. Little Lemur plan: max 1 million messages/month, max 20 concurrent connections, max 100 queues, max 10,000 queued messages, multiple nodes in different AZ's
  • serveo.net â€” Quickly expose any local port to the public internet on a servo subdomain using an SSH tunnel, includes SSH GUI to replay requests over HTTP.
  • ZeroTier â€” FOSS managed virtual Ethernet as a service. Unlimited end-to-end encrypted networks of 100 clients on free plan. Clients for desktop/mobile/NA; web interface for configuration of custom routing rules and approval of new client nodes on private networks.
  • Hamachi â€” LogMeIn Hamachi is a hosted VPN service that lets you securely extend LAN-like networks to distributed teams with free plan allows unlimited networks with up to 5 peoples
  • webhookrelay.com â€” Manage, debug, fan-out and proxy all your webhooks to public or internal (ie: localhost) destinations. Also, expose servers running in a private networks over a tunnel by getting a public HTTP endpoint (https://yoursubdomain.webrelay.io <----> http://localhost:8080).
